title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) – In a performance that will be etched into the annals of franchise lore, Gary Payton authored a masterpiece on his home floor. “The Glove” was not merely good; he was historically dominant, leading the Seattle SuperSonics to a commanding 108-96 victory over the Sacramento Kings.

Payton was simply unguardable, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 43 points. He was a whirlwind of offensive fury, slicing through the Kings’ defense at will. His mid-range jumper was automatic, and his forays to the basket were both relentless and graceful. This was not just a scoring outburst; it was a complete takeover, a virtuoso performance that left the Seattle Coliseum crowd in a state of rapture.

While Payton’s scoring was the headline, his backcourt partner, Hersey Hawkins, provided the perfect complementary act. Hawkins chipped in 20 points, stretching the defense and ensuring Sacramento could never fully commit to slowing Payton down.

The Kings, led by 22 points from Corliss Williamson and a strong 17-point, 13-rebound double-double from Otis Thorpe, fought valiantly but had no answer for the Payton onslaught. Mitch Richmond, their primary scorer, was held to a quiet 12 points, suffocated by the very defense Payton’s nickname represents.

On a night where one man ascended to a historic peak, the outcome was never in doubt. The Sonics rode the hot hand of their floor general, a performance for the ages from Gary Payton, to a decisive win. It was a night that reminded everyone why he was one of the most formidable and complete guards of his generation.
